comment: Smooth, sweet, caramel corn, graham cracker, balanced, cherry
Nose of sweet butter and oak, with maybe a hint of tobacco tanginess. Brown sugar and tobacco flavor. Lightly spicy, short, wheat-tingle finish. Very smooth and satisfying. Love it.
Love this. Huge step up from the original Maker’s Mark. Vanilla definitely comes through strong.

BACKGROUND: When it was originally released in 2010, Maker’s 46 was the first new expression developed and sold by Maker’s Mark in 50 years, and because the company was famous for sticking to the traditional and not upending the marketplace, it created a bit of a splash (no pun intended).

In 2008, Bill Samuels, Jr., the son of the brand’s founder, decided it was time to develop a new line, and he assigned the task to Master Distiller Kevin Smith.  The assignment included some specific instructions from Samuels, which included:

The new whisky had to be sweeter than the current Maker’s Mark and contain distinct caramel notes. 

It would have a toasty wood aroma. 

The finished product needed a lingering, rather than a crisp, flavor. 

It couldn’t have any sour notes, especially the bitter flavors in the back of the throat that drinkers might get from other brands. 

After much experimentation, the Maker’s 46 formula and process was decided upon.

The bourbon begins as regular Maker’s Mark distillate, but after its normal period of aging, it is placed in a second standard barrel containing ten French oak staves and aged in a temperature-controlled limestone cave for an additional period.  

This oak staves are first aged nine to 12 months, up to three months longer than the normal length of time for standard barrel wood, in order to remove bitter tannins, and they are toasted rather than charred, which results in specific flavors. 

NOSE: The nose carries a strong scents of cherry cordial and fresh-baked bread.  Caramel is present, as well.  It is a pleasant nose, and one that finds me lingering over the glencairn to enjoy it before every sip.

PALATE: The strong cherry presence in the nose manifests upon the palate, as well, but it is joined by a nice chocolate toffee flavor.  Some maple syrup, oak, and a bit of spice are present, as well.

FINISH: The long and warming finish is dominated by oak, but contrary to Bill Samuels Jr.’s instructions, it offers deeply bitter and unpleasant tannins. 

FINAL ASSESSMENT: The nose shines the most, by far, in this bourbon, but the palate is also pleasant.  The bitterness on the finish, however, becomes more pronounced with each sip and takes away some of the enjoyment.

Honestly, I discovered this bottle in the back of my bourbon cabinet and had completely forgotten that I even owned it, but that pretty much sums up my thoughts about this bourbon.  It is not great, and it is not bad.  It is just simply average and, in a word, “forgettable.”

Hard to beat this at the price point.  Delicious neat or on ice ball.
Well rounded, woodsy and sweet and almost completely devoid of any harshness.
This is my go to Makers for both on ice and in an Old Fashion

I don't care for regular Maker's Mark or the MM Cask Strength, but I really like Maker's 46.  Got a few bottles on sale recently for $24 a piece, and this is definitely my favorite daily drinker.  

Just a smooth, solid drinker with cocoa and jam notes. It's like the chocolate cake of bourbon: nothing mind blowing but who can complain about chocolate cake
Nose has a hint of chocolate. Kind of a typical wheater, not as good as others. But I wouldn't refuse it....

The nose of the bourbon features spicy notes of cinnamon and vanilla.

On the palate it is a smooth drink with a pleasant spice.  It carries the cinnamon promised in the nose and delivers beautifully on woody vanilla flavors.
Salty, savoury, woody, sweet vanilla, dark chocolate, espresso, smokey cheddar, cherry, raisin, bitter burnt toast. Smooth, spicy finish.
This is so much nicer than regular Makers. Smoother with a more noticeable woodsy finish

This is actually a very good bourbon. 47%abv,  a much better expression than the original Maker's Mark. Very mellowed and easy to drink even if it is 47%abv. Beautiful red color.

It is called Maker's 46 because the story of this dram goes, allegedly, like this: after making the normal "Maker's Mark", they take some barrels apart and add some diferent french oak stakes to the barrel giving it a flavor enhancement, and they came to that recipe after 46 attempts.... it actually works like a charm.

On the nose, typical bourbon notes, very pleasant: Vainilla ice cream, Banana, Cinnamon and Maple syrup.

On the palate, caramel, Herbal liquorice, Allspice, Vanilla. Very Mellowed, very easy, lovely really.

Clove or allspice aftertaste, medium long.

This fine bourbon deserves a 88 over 100 and for the price, i say you should grab a bottle. Cheers!

Nose - Gentle cinnamon spices 

Palate - Starts gentle and sweet then onwards from the finish goes increasingly spicy
A more robust flavor profile but similar to regular makers. I’m not the biggest fan of regular makers neat, but this one is a good sipper
Sweet nose and palate with plenty of vanilla. Rounded short to medium finish. A definate improvement to the standard Marker's Mark.

Toffee and coffee, cherries and vanilla pudding on the nose. Hits the palate with a sweet cinnamon oak tone, strong barrel presence midway through with the spice and oak. Much more interesting than the standard makers, would drink this neat over it.
Light on the front, smooth finish
Solid bourbon you can find everyday.  Very underrated.
Cherry at front changing to Carmel with a vanilla finish. Smooth rounded
Nice, fruity, less of the grainy wheat funk. Light airy baking spices which a delicate soft herbal and honey note. Very robust but delicate char note. Medium finish, not a harsh burn.
I mean, I liked it a lot. I don’t remember exactly what I liked about it.. but the bottle didn’t last long!

This is a wheated bourbon, so the sweetness makes itself known on arrival.  Brown sugar developing into vanilla, then hints of butterscotch.  The oak doesn't make an appearance until the second sip, and it slowly gains traction from a malt-like mid-palate to a dry finish.  Subsequent nosing reflects the initial palate.  Adding water rounds out the sweetness, reminding me of vanilla ice cream.  This is when I start smacking my lips to accommodate and enjoy the finish.  Good work.



My Rating Glossary:  

Two Stars:           "I'd rather be drinking lite beer."
Two 1/2 Stars:    "Posh rubbish."
Three Stars:        "I love whisk(e)y.  This is average love."
Three 1/2 Stars: "May buy again."
Four Stars:          "I've got to get you into my life."
Four 1/2 Stars:   "Better than drugs."
Five Stars:           "Life is good.  Whisky makes it better."
Very understated lite vanilla nose, then stronger spicy finish.  Like a nice kayak trip down a gentle flowing river.... could drink it all day.

the nose: sweet apple, vanilla, oak, fresh baked bread. 

the palate: the start is sweet that turns into oak, vanilla, buttery fresh baked bread. the tail end is a nice warm rum like flavor and cinnamon.
Meh. Worth a try, but something in the secondary wood finish is off-putting to me. I much prefer regular Maker’s, especially with it’s smaller price tag.
Very sweet on the nose and palate. Maraschino cherries and hint of wood spice, with brown sugar throughout. Sweet and tasty enough to be dessert.

Tart but light, like a Pear.. fruity but peppery on finish 
best bourbon in months due to difference in character
Very spicy with a lot of vanilla notes.

Nose: cherry, vanilla, oak, cinnamon
Taste: bright fruit(cherry and apple), vanilla, pepper, oak
Finish: moderate length, vanilla, pepper, oak and charcoal

Nose: Vanilla, baking spice, dried fruits and oak with hints of tobacco and cherries

Palate: Oak, vanilla, cinnamon, tobacco and hints of fruit

Finish: Rounded finish with oak and hints of spice

Makers 46 is for the most part your typical bourbon. There some nice hints of fruit with vanilla and cinnamon ever present. The finish is rounded and doesn’t leave much for you to contemplate.
A small step up from ungreat

Nose
Caramel, spice, chocolate, butterscotch 

Palate
Spice
Oak
Dark chocolate 
Cherry
Butterscotch
Vanilla nose with a sweet oak and cinnamon taste.  Quite different from regular Maker’s Mark.

I feel like I’m have a Goldilocks moment here. I’ll drink the original Makers any day, but it can come across a bit thin. On the flip side, the Makers CS was too much for me to handle, time and air did t open it up, and I ended up gifting it to a friend. This seems to be filling that “just right” bucket for me. On the nose......

A lovely nose to ponder. Brown sugar, butter, cinnamon...like a softer version of Wild Turkey but no less full bodied. It enters the palate gently, with a burst of spice on the mid palate, and then its smooth as butter going down. That mid-palate is important. That’s what I’m missing in the classic Makers, and that’s the clear influence of the French Oak (a lesson won by spending all last year getting to know a bottle of Compass Box Spice Tree). The finish is subtle but lingers. A gentle reminder of what you just drank, like a liquid cinnamon bun. 

A worth purchase. I was looking for a bourbon to get me through the summer, and this will do ever so nicely. At $30, it’s a great price too. I like the wheaters, bit I don’t really want to shell out for Weller, and this fits the bill well. Cheers!
Another very nice bourbon for the price point

A fuller, spicier version of the standard Maker’s Mark, and for me that’s a good thing.  The overall impression is a fluffy honey-wheat bagel.  Shows cinnamon and a little caramel on the nose, backed by Bit-O-Honey and Wheaties on the palate.  It’s somehow focused and round at the same time, and it complicates things with some minerality on a medium-length finish.  I love this at the price.
Very good. End of night ritual

Head & shoulders above regular Maker’s this expression is quite nice. As a neat pour or with some ice this offers a warming, cocoa infused, toasted oak dram with great body, sweetness and a touch of spice. Where I found this really shines is in cocktails like Boulevardier or Manhattan where a creamier Bourbon is preferred overpower, char & spice.
Very very sweet. Has a boozy taste without water. The water helped bring out more flavor
Very very sweet. Has a spice to it. Without any added water is kind of boozy - but it is cask strength. After adding a little water, it opens more taste. Still really sweet
Very very sweet. Has a spice to it. Without any added water is kind of boozy - but it is cask strength. After adding a little water, it opens more taste. Still really sweet
Just as good as the classic but with more nuance and complex flavors.
Classic Maker’s vanilla oak spice, wood char, slightly short Maker’s finish
Brown sugar with toasted cherry pie after second taste.
Really smooth blend even at the cask strength. Easy drinking and the high wheat mash bill doesn’t come off as too strong in any way.
Amazing. Very smooth. A touch of sweetness. I hope they keep making it.
A lot more oaker then I remember.  Nice spicy flavor profile that gives away to the classic cherry vanilla notes Makers is known form. Nice step up from the traditional Maker's Mark.
Just a great smell and taste. Definitely the best that I have tried in the price range
Smooth & flavorful start. Wood flavor throughout. Quicker finish with a strong oak flavor, with hints of cinnamon/ vanilla. Very solid and drinkable bourbon. Should be related to Woody Double Oak
An upgrade to og makers more wood and a sort of rich mocha/chocolate taste
Good, smooth bourbon? Yes. Worth the price tag? Absolutely not. Not enough interesting stuff going on here.
Caramel and vanilla smell.  Slightly caramel taste with extra vanilla, followed by an oak finish.

On the nose the first thing that jumps out is a strong oak that gives way to a creamy vanilla and the final note that I get is orange zest that was just squeezed onto an old fashioned

On the pallet there is a spicy vanilla followed by a short oaky finish

Vanilla, caramel, and a floral note on the nose. Simple but pleasant.
Sweet on the palate - not quite maple syrup-like but almost like I want to drizzle this on some French toast. The oak and caramel from the nose are evident on the palate as well.
A leathery, oak finish fades quickly. It’s quite short. Hoping for more but it gets me going back for another sip.

A fine drink. I won’t be in a hurry to replace this bottle once I finish it, but I’d buy it again at some point.
Rich and vanilla with some spice. Taste similar to regular Maker’s, but with more spice.
Custardy vanilla nose, warm pudding note. Spicy oak, more vanilla & a short burn on the taste...finishes easy with just a couple touches of fruits & astringency.
Vanilla and ripe apples on the nose. Baking spice upfront then a creamy vanilla and caramel note on the mid. Excellent for the price and always available in Michigan.
Buttery, caramel, vanilla, popcorn. Love it.
This takes the standard above the line!  Best neat to really taste the oak at the end.
